Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, dinner at 7! Mom’s making your favorite.” I could almost hear her voice, warm and insistent, reminding me how much it meant to everyone that I show up. Family dinners were sacred—an unspoken rule in our house. But my laptop chimed with a new email from my manager, subject line urgent: “Updated safety standard—need documentation by tomorrow morning.” My heart sank. The new regulation was complex, and I was the only one on the team who fully understood the system. If I didn’t get the evidence together tonight, the release would be delayed, and the company could face penalties. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family expecting my laughter at the table, my team relying on my expertise. I wanted to be the dependable sister and the responsible engineer, but tonight, I couldn’t see how to be both. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between replying to my sister and opening the compliance checklist, my mind racing with guilt and frustration.
